Textual Editing with the TEI
Or,
Documentary Editing with the TEI
Or,
What is genetic criticism and why are they saying such strange things about it?

list.item: Its a text !
It's a document !
It's a moment in a developing process !

div.head: A text is not a document
div.p:
Where is the text? How is it defined?
by the shape of letters and their layout?
by a specific document from which other versions are derived?
by its author's (presumed) intentions?
by the stories we read into it?
A "document" is something that exists in the world, which we can digitize.
A "text" is an abstraction, created by or for a community of readers, which we can encode.

div.head: It's the Text Encoding Initiative, innit ?
div.p: Up to a point, Lord Copper ...

The TEI already provides many documentary features:
critical apparatus
textual transcription
manuscript metadata
digital facsimile editions
In this talk, we review (some of) these from the documentary editing perspective, and discuss some proposed extension of them.

div.head: Textual Editing with the TEI
div.p:
Topics we will (partly) cover:
Texts vs. documents
TEI markup for (old skool) critapp
TEI markup for transcriptional elements
TEI genetic markup

Topics we won't :
Creating facsimile editions
Documenting sources with msDesc
Software for managing, creating, or visualising scholarly editions
TEI for epigraphy -- that's coming soon!

div.head: Theoretical underpinnings
div.p: In a perfect world, textual editing would be unnecessary (Lance Schachterle)

Textual editing inevitably reflects a theoretical stance about what a text is, or should be. But there are many conflicting theories/traditions about the editing of texts:
Greg, Bowers, McKerrow, Tanselle et al.
Greetham, McCann, Shillingsburg ...
historisch-kritische Ausgabe (aka The Germans)
l'édition génétique (aka The French)
As facilitator of multiple theories, the TEI tries to avoid a theoretical stance, but rarely succeeds ...

div.head: Old Skool Textual Criticism
div.p: This sort of thing...
A complex print format containing information whose structure it might be useful to encode... cf dictionaries.

div.head: Looking closer at a simple example
div.p:
The following line from Hamlet might be printed as:
LAERTES. Alas, then she is drowned.
together with the following critical apparatus:
4.7.156 Alas, then is she drowned.] HIBBARD; Alas then, is she drown'd? F; Alas then is she drownd. Q3; Alas, then, she is drownd. Q2; So, she is drownde: Q1.

div.head: Critical Apparatus: app, rdg, and lem

list.item: (apparatus entry) contains one entry in a critical apparatus, with an optional lemma and at least one reading.
(reading) contains a single reading within a textual variation.
(lemma) contains the lemma, or base text, of a textual variation.

div.head: Granularity of variation is up to the encoder
Topic creep alert.
div.p: Note that the labels (#Hib, #Q1 etc.) are URLs : they point to something, in this case a piece of metadata about the particular witness.
Manuscript metadata is another major topic in the TEI (see discussion of msDesc) : it is provided not only for documentary purposes, but also to facilitate quantitative codicology.

div.head: Further refinements are possible...

list.item: Readings common to all witnesses may be factored out
Readings common to some witnesses may be grouped, using rdgGroup, witList etc.
Other special tricks may be needed for lacunae, re-orderings, etc.

div.p: Even with these, the format is not sufficient to reliably regenerate the original sources, nor (probably) to represent efficiently the output from an automatic collation programn.

div.p:
Three methods are proposed:
Location reference
Double end-point attachment
Parallel segmentation

div.head: Better models for text variation

list.item: See detailed comments from the TEI MS SIG review of this chapter (http://wiki.tei-c.org/index.php/Critical_Apparatus_Workgroup).

In particular see Schmidt's model of multiversion documents:
http://multiversiondocs.blogspot.com

Not unlike Sperberg-McQueen's Rhine-delta model from 1989 http://cmsmcq.com/1989/rhine-delta-abstract.html, this probably provides a better data structure for representing the results of automatic collation.

div.p: In fact it seems that people don't care that much about pre-existing collations. They want to make their own, sharing outputs from collation engines such as Juxta.

div.head: Transcription of primary sources using the TEI

list.item: text : contains a structured reading of a document's intellectual content ... its text
facsimile : organizes a set of page images representing a document
teiHeader : provides metadata for the whole thing, at various levels, notably including a msDesc

div.p: Does a transcription encode a text or a document ?

list.item: agreable is struck-through, pleasing is written above it, in the interlinear space.
agreable is deleted and replaced by pleasing

div.head: Transcription: a special kind of reading
div.p:
What is the goal of a transcription?
to make a primary source accessible ...
... and comprehensible
which may imply adding or using much additional information

Hence,
all transcription is selective
all transcription is imaginative

div.head: Transcription for the digital edition
div.p:
Some textual phenomena which commonly attract editorial attention :
original layout information
abbreviations or other arcana
evident errors which invite correction or conjecture
scribal additions, deletions, substitutions, restorations
non-standard orthography (etc.) which invites normalisation
irrelevant or non-transcribable material
passages which are damaged or illegible

div.head: Original layout information
div.p:
The TEI privileges the logical view, but does permit the physical view to show through as empty milestone elements :
gb the start of a new gathering or quire
pb the start of a new page
cb the start of a new column
lb the start of a new written line
These are primarily useful to establish a reference system.
The fw element can be used to mark paratextual features such as running heads, foliotation etc.
The handShift element can be used to mark changes of hand or writing in a document.

div.head: Abbreviations &c.
div.p:
In Western MSS, we commonly distinguish : Suspensions
the first letter or letters of the word are written, generally followed by a point : for example e.g. for exempla gratia Contractions
both first and last letters are written, generally with some mark of abbreviation such as superscript strokes, or points : e.g. Mr. for Mister Brevigraphs
Special signs such as the Tironian nota used for et, the letter p with a barred tail used for per, the letter c with a circumflex used for cum etc. Superscripts
Superscript letters (vowels or consonants) used to indicate various kinds of contraction: e.g. w followed by superscript ch for which.
Most of the symbols needed are available in Unicode, though not necessarily in all fonts.

div.head: Abbreviation and Expansion
div.p:
An abbreviation may be viewed in two different ways:
as a particular sequence of letters or marks upon the pa thus, a ‘p with a bar through the descender’, a ‘superscript hook’, a ‘macron’
as another way of representing the letter or letters it is believed to be standing for: thus, ‘per’, ‘re’, ‘n'

div.head: Two Levels of Encoding Abbreviations
div.p:
TEI proposes elements for two levels of encoding:
the whole of an abbreviated word and the whole of its expansion may be marked using abbr and expan respectively
abbreviatory signs or characters and the invisible characters they imply may be marked using am and ex respectively

div.head: A simple example (1)
div.p:
Editorial strategy may be simply to note that we have expanded the abbreviations:
Cours chacune piece pour
cinquante soubz tournois.

div.head: A simple example (2)
div.p: As you noticed, pour was actually written po followed by an r subscript; cinquante as cinquāte with a macron on the a to indicate nasalisation.

We could therefore encode as follows:
po� .... cinquāte

... or we could choose one of the following styles:
po� ... or pour
po�
pour

div.head: Simple example (3)
Classifying abbreviations
div.p:
The type attribute on abbr is a useful way of categorising abbreviations, whether for statistical purposes, or to allow for different types to be rendered differently:
po� pour en fin.finir
This encoding might be displayed as : po(u)r en finir
As elsewhere, the resp and cert attributes can also be used to indicate who is responsible for an expansion, and the degree of certainty attached to it.

div.head: Corrections and emendations
div.p: The sic element can be used to indicate that the reading of the manuscript is erroneous or nonsensical, while corr (correction) can be used to provide what in the editor's opinion is the correct reading: relea relicta

The two may, of course, be combined within a choice element:
relea relicta relatio

div.head: Normalization
div.p: Source texts rarely use modern orthography. For retrieval and other processing reasons, however, the modernized form may be very. The reg (regularized) element is available used to mark a normalized form; the orig (original) element to indicate a non-standard spelling. These elements can optionally be grouped as alternatives using the choice element:

div.head: Normalisation example
div.p:
In this case, a further semantic regularisation is possible :
dix huicthuit grains troys quartztrois-quart

div.head: Additions, deletions, and substitutions
div.p: Alterations made to the text, whether by the scribe or in some later hand, can be encoded using add (addition) or del (deletion).

Where the addition and deletion are regarded as a single substitution, they can be grouped together using the subst (substitution) element :
add (addition) or del (deletion) are used for evident alterations in the source
a combined addition and deletion may be marked using subst (substitution)

egXML.l: And towards our distant rest began to trudge,
Helping the worst amongst us Dragging the worst amongt us , who'd no boots
Drunk with fatigue ; deaf even to the hoots
Of tired, outstripped fif five-nines that dropped behind.

div.head: Semi-legible text
div.p: Use unclear if the text is partly illegible i.e. it can be read but without perfect confidence. The reason attribute here states the cause of the uncertainty in transcription.

div.head: Supplied and damaged text
div.p: Use the supplied element if the transcriber has provided a reading not actually visible in the text, whether because of damage or scribal error : reason here indicates why the text has been supplied.

Use the damage element to record the existence of physical damage to the document, whether or not the damaged text is readable :
The Moving Finger wries; and having writ,
Moves on: nor all your Piety nor Wit

div.head: Lacunae
div.p: When missing text cannot be confidently supplied, the gap element should be used. Its reason attribute explains the reason for the omission and its extent and unit attributes indicate its size.

p.egXML: I am dr Sr yr Sydney Smith

div.head: Some difficulties
div.p:
These methods are perfectly adequate where variation is comparatively simple. They rapidly encounter problems when:
overlap happens (as it always does)
the sequence of interventions is important or indeterminate
the layout and the meaning of the writing are not easily separable
Work-arounds do exist for all of these, of course

div.head: Additions and deletions crossing element boundaries
div.p: When additions and deletions are not conveniently well-nested within other parts of the structure, we can use spanning techniques.
The elements addSpan and delSpan delimit a span of text by pointing mechanisms rather than by enclosing it.
spanTo indicates the end of a span initiated by the element bearing this attribute.

div.head: Underspecification
div.p: The Guidelines are a bit vague on how exactly spanning works.

Consider
apple banana
cherrydate
Does this mean
apple date
or
apple
date
?

div.head: Using attributes to clarify who did what when

list.item: The author (WJ) wrote One must have lived...
The author added the word But before One
An editor (FB) corrected One to one

div.egXML:

One one must have lived ...
editorial changes Fredson Bowers

div.head: Using restore to indicate authorial change of mind

list.item: The author writes For I hate this my body
The word my is deleted
The author writes stet in the margin

div.p:
The restore element can be used to indicate that a deletion has been reversed:
[...] For I hate this my body [...]
... note that we have not encoded the metamark stet, but rather its effect.

div.head: How far will the TEI take us ?
div.p: In particular, is the TEI scheme adequate for the needs of those transcribing modern manuscripts ?

list.item: surviving medieval or early modern manuscripts generally have a public function, and a more or less conventionalised (if complex) format
modern manuscripts or authorial drafts however often contain entirely private or idiosyncratic signs, with no clear communicative function

div.head: Text/Image
div.p: At all periods we find playful texts whose meaning is conveyed by their documentary appearance as much as by their linguistic properties, or by the interplay between the two.
The TEI initially ruled such texts out of scope, for a variety of reasons, not least a dearth of image-processing technologies.

div.head: Concerns that won't go away

list.item: The process by which a document was created may be as important as its final or canonical textual form

It may be impossible to talk about the text independently of its documentary instantiation, whether because
the meaning of the text is presented entirely or partly graphically
the document is deliberately constructed in a non-linear or combinatorial way, in order to generate many texts

div.p: Les textes non-linéaires sont des non-textes (Daniel Ferrer)

div.head: Document vs. text
div.p:
By hypothesis, distinguishing these levels may help our editorial task :
at the documentary level : pages, surfaces, writing, tears, crossings-out, stains...
at the textual level : corrections, modifications, additions, deletions, transpositions...
Distinguishing these levels in our encoding is the only way to identify their interaction

div.head: Some extra features in TEI for documentary editing
div.p:
A workgroup with participation from several major current editorial projects produced a set of recommendations currently working through the TEI Council. In summary, the group suggested :
A sourceDoc element
Several additional transcriptional elements
Mechanisms for the explicit documentation of writing stages or layers

div.head: First proposal: a new element
div.p: The sourceDoc element

list.item: a sibling of text teiHeader and facsimile
represents the physical structure of a document, in terms of written surfaces, and zones of writing.
a line element is added to represent topographic lines

div.head: The Robinsonian edition
div.p:
Peter Robinson is good at provocation:
One may contemplate, with equanimity, every complexity of Byzantine medieval military history but be quite defeated by the unfamiliar vocabulary of the mysteriously interconnected universe which is the TEI. the first issue of Digital Medievalist
In an article in computerphilogie (2005), he makes the very good point that a digital edition really should do more than a print edition ...

p.q: almost without exception, no scholarly electronic edition has presented material which could not have been presented in book form ... most electronic scholarly editions [fail] to use new computer methodologies to explore the texts which they present

div.head: So what should we anticipate doing with the editions of the future?

list.item: Better visualisation tools
Better access mechanisms, for both metadata and data
Tools for dynamic hypothesis testing
More use of social networking and crowd sourcing

div.head: New technical paradigms
div.p:
Visualisation and analysis at two levels
sub-documentary components
across corpora of documents
locating and presenting for patterns of variation
quantitative codicology meets evolutionary biology

div.head: The wisdom of crowds and the demise of the editor
div.p: We are all engaged in the business of understanding: distributed editions fashioned collaboratively may become the ground of our mutual enterprise. (PMWR, 2007)
